qas.question: The rule of liability for defective products originated from what law?
In what case did the supreme court of California, throw away warranties and strictly impose liability for defective products?
What was most influential American 20th century tort law?

answers.text: rule of strict liability for defective products

qas.question: What year was the case Greenman v. Yuba Power products?
What is one of the most influential changes to tort law?

answers.text: rule of strict liability for defective products

qas.question: Who was at the forefront of the fight to change the laws on defective products?
What case was fundamental in the fight to change warranty laws?
When was the Greenman rule in Section 402A of the Restatement (Second) of Torts published?
When was the Restatement (Second) of Torts beginning to be adopted outside of the United States?
What section of the Product Liability Directive discusses warranties?
What minor rule went on the books on the 20th c?
Who is the head of the American Law Institute?
When did Traynor publish the Restatement (Second) of Torts?

context: Notably, the most broadly influential innovation of 20th-century American tort law was the <a2_0><a4_0>rule of <b11_0>strict liability for defective products<b11_0/><a4_0/><a2_0/>, which originated with judicial glosses on the <a0_0>law of warranty<a0_0/>. In <a3_0>1963<a3_0/>, <a5_0><b12_0>Roger J. Traynor<b12_0/><a5_0/> of the Supreme Court of California threw away legal fictions based on warranties and imposed strict liability for defective products as a matter of public policy in the landmark case of <a1_0><a6_0><b9_0>Greenman v. Yuba Power Products<b9_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/>. The American Law Institute subsequently adopted a slightly different version of the Greenman rule in Section <b10_0>402A<b10_0/> of the Restatement (Second) of Torts, which was published in <a7_0><b13_0>1964<b13_0/><a7_0/> and was very influential throughout the United States. Outside the U.S., the rule was adopted by the European Economic Community in the Product Liability Directive of July <a8_0>1985<a8_0/> by Australia in July 1992 and by Japan in June 1994.
